intro: Ptilotus divaricatus, commonly known as the "ghost flower," is a flowering plant native to Australia. It belongs to the Malvaceae family and is characterized by its unique, fluffy, pink or purple seed heads that resemble clouds. The plant typically grows in arid and semi-arid regions, thriving in sandy or rocky soils. It produces showy, pale yellow flowers that bloom in late winter to early spring. The plant is often cultivated for its ornamental value and is also used in traditional Indigenous practices.
